configuration.courseTitle: Assessment and Treatment of Trauma Precourse Module

resource.narrationText: Being able to appropriately treat a patient depends on a correct assessment of the problem. This segment explains how to organize an efficient assessment so the correct decision can be made quickly.
Because assessment can be complex, it is often broken into several phases. Each phase follows in a logical order as a call progresses.

Before even looking at the patient, the first step is to survey the scene surroundings. This scene size-up should focus on issues of safety—for yourself, other responders, the public, and then the patient, in that order. Signs of danger include spilled fluids and downed or hanging wires. Most important at traffic collisions is the traffic still flowing around the site. Next determine the number of patients involved. Remember that more than one patient without an obvious cause of injury or illness may indicate a hazardous atmosphere. The next assessment of the scene should be to determine the mechanism of injury. Knowing the mechanism of injury can help guide the responder to look for specific possible injuries. Based on this information, a decision on the need to call for additional resources can be made.

The initial, or primary, assessment looks for immediate life threats. Treatment should immediately follow discovery. The Airway, Breathing, Circulation (ABC) order is based on the concept that oxygen needs to make its way down the airway and into the lungs in order to be circulated to the cells. This survey should be performed in order, and if a problem is found, it must be dealt with using BLS measures.

Immediate trauma care is geared toward finding and treating life threats. This approach follows the ABCs, but two critical issues need to be addressed first: c-spine stabilization and major bleeding control. The four major airway problems you may find during the initial assessment include liquids, such as blood and emesis; solids (foreign body airway obstruction); the tongue; and swelling or a crushing injury that leads to anatomical obstruction. Major breathing problems include open pneumothorax, tension pneumothorax, flail chest, and low minute volume. Any patient whose breathing rate is lower than 8 to 10 breaths per minute or above 30 breaths per minute will have dangerously reduced minute volume. Primary circulatory problems include a pulse rate below 50 or above 160, severe bleeding, and signs of shock. The patient's mental status may be the prime indicator of how sick the patient is and may provide clues to the patient's condition. Use the AVPU mnemonic and the Glascow Coma Scale to assess mental status and neurologic function.

Early in the assessment process, you need to identify priority patients who will benefit from limited time at the scene and rapid transport. When you have a priority patient, it is important that you expedite transport and minimize scene time. You should do only what is absolutely necessary at the scene and handle everything else en route, including the appropriate focused history and physical examination. A number of factors may lead you to determine that a patient is a priority, including: poor general impression, unresponsiveness, altered mentation, difficulty breathing, hypoperfusion or shock, uncontrolled bleeding, severe pain, or multiple injuries. Those patients who do not pass the initial/primary assessment are unstable and should be transported to the appropriate hospital as soon as possible.

The rapid trauma/secondary assessment is performed after the initial assessment and after all life threats to airway, breathing, and circulation have been identified and addressed. This exam consists of quickly examining the patient systematically from the head to the toes to locate additional injuries. If the patient requires rapid transport, the physical exam should be conducted after transport is initiated.

For patients who are showing signs of shock, treatment on scene should be limited to opening the airway, ensuring adequate ventilation and oxygenation, and controlling external blood loss. This includes decompressing tension pneumothoricies, closing sucking chest wounds, and establishing whole-body splinting with a long backboard for immediate transport. For critical patients already showing signs of shock, only perform lifesaving interventions on scene prior to rapid transport to a trauma facility that offers surgical intervention and blood transfusion.

Trauma patients may present with multisystem trauma. With these patients, you must continually think about how each of the various injuries you find relates to the others. Complete a rapid trauma/secondary assessment, provide care to the support the ABCs as needed, and take necessary spinal precautions. A long backboard may be used to splint the body globally and minimize the chance of further injury to isolated fractures. Additional assessment and treatment can be conducted en route to the hospital.

Those patients whose ABCs are stable can have more complete examination and treatment on scene prior to a safe and careful transport.

The decision of transport destination is usually guided by point-of-entry plans that are part of local protocols. Protocols usually address the mechanism of injury, anatomic location of injuries, and physiologic indicators such as blood pressure. Time to transport should go into the decision to call for air transport along with cost and safety. Often the availability of air transport is dictated by the weather.

All treatment is based on careful assessment and determination of the problem. Once life threats are identified and addressed, additional assessment can be initiated based on the patient’s condition and priority level. Transport the patient to the facility that is best equipped to meet his or her needs.
